channel.title: Initial Stack is null?
channel.description:
Whenever trying to decompile/deobfuscate the classes in the loader.jar file from the runescape website, I always seem to have a AssertError thrown at me.
Class5 and the Applet_Sub1 class both seem to have this error, so they don't get decompiled. I know that I'm not going to be spoon fed any answers, or any type of way to completely fix this, but somebody tell me at least what is causing this error, because I can try to fix it after that...
How did this have to do with RS2 client hacking?
I was told that, in order to load a modified client, I was going to have to somehow make the loader load my files. So I was thinking that I would decompile it then take it from there.
Thanks, if you post, for trying to help.
Before you people tell me what to do, I already looked into jode, and took a look at the classes that were defined in these errors.

item.title: Initial Stack is null?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

That isn’t the only way. I turn Javascript off, which is legitimate, then you can choose the unsigned client under java options, then just load up the unsigned client regularly.

Read full topic

item.title: Initial Stack is null?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Where is the link for that? Or the condition under which its loaded?

EDIT: Oh cheers ollie

Read full topic

item.title: Initial Stack is null?
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Mopman:

Do they still allow you to run an unsigned client though the normal site? Last time I checked they removed that, which would be a tip-off in itself… then again I’m pretty unobservant.

the only way to run it is when the hd client fails,
it will redirect you to www.runescape.com/slu.ws and will launch an unsigned applet

[quote=“Jagex”]You are seeing this page because we could not start RuneScape on your computer in ‘signed’ mode. This means that you did not (or were not able to) grant permission to RuneScape to run as it normally does. To avoid seeing this page again, please ensure that you accept the pop-up security warning that appears a few seconds after loading the game. If this pop-up does not appear, try rebooting your machine and make sure you click ‘Yes’ when asked if you want to trust the RuneScape applet.

Loading and running the game ‘unsigned’ like this takes much longer, as it must re-download all the content every time you play; you will also be unable to use RuneScape’s high detail graphics mode or use the in-game world switcher without reloading the game.

To work around this, you may use this page to manually select a world and then load the game. Please be aware that loading the game from this page will always load the unsigned game, so you should only use this page if you really have no other option.[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: Initial Stack is null?
item.dc:creator: @Metho_D Method
item.description:
@Metho_D wrote:

Yes, it’s still available to run from the site.

item.title: Initial Stack is null?
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

dont block it, reroute it. iirc java7 will have a better abstraction of the filesystem, whether this would help or not is another thing

Read full topic

item.title: Initial Stack is null?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

It can be worked around like you said of course, problem is you have to detect what they are doing to know how to work around it, and what if they do things you don’t detect? A safer way is to make sure they can never do anything no matter what, so use an unsigned client.

Read full topic

item.title: Initial Stack is null?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

I wouldn’t use a custom loader I would use a custom java.io.File. I’m sure there is a deeper java layer or ‘bottle neck’ where it would be possible to reroute file access.

Blocking permissions is an issue. Other than accessing the Calender when the Policy is checked not much happens. I thought it would be sufficient until they concentrated on detecting the bot and even if they did successive layers of camouflage could be used in a similar manner to File.

Read full topic

item.title: Initial Stack is null?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

@frank_ also:

[quote=“BAsh, post:10, topic:252364”]I would implement a security manager. Let it do what it wants to the cache and any other permissions prompt the user. Maybe cache the answers so they aren’t DOSed.

The only hard bit is redirecting access to the cache on a per client basis rather than per user/os.[/quote]

It would still be able to detect that the user is blocking these permissions, and that the cache isn’t where they told it to be, the only way for that to happen is with a custom loader so they would ban you. (or at least detect you)

The only completely undetectable way to do it is to use the unsigned client.

Read full topic

item.title: Initial Stack is null?
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:9, topic:252364”]If you allow the client to access your whole hard drive and network (after all, a signed client has basically the same permissions as an application) then you have to be paranoid and check for all of the nasty horrible things they can do to detect your cheating, identify and ban you.

However, if you run the unsigned client exactly like an unsigned client should be ran, it can only call home to the server you got it from and can’t access your computer or network otherwise. You never have to check anything because they can only do what you want them to do.[/quote]basically the only reason you wouldnt do it is because you are too lazy to write a decent system?

Read full topic

item.title: Initial Stack is null?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

I would implement a security manager. Let it do what it wants to the cache and any other permissions prompt the user. Maybe cache the answers so they aren’t DOSed.

The only hard bit is redirecting access to the cache on a per client basis rather than per user/os.

Read full topic

item.title: Initial Stack is null?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

If you allow the client to access your whole hard drive and network (after all, a signed client has basically the same permissions as an application) then you have to be paranoid and check for all of the nasty horrible things they can do to detect your cheating, identify and ban you.

However, if you run the unsigned client exactly like an unsigned client should be ran, it can only call home to the server you got it from and can’t access your computer or network otherwise. You never have to check anything because they can only do what you want them to do.

Read full topic

item.title: Initial Stack is null?
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:7, topic:252364”]It’s best not to mess with loader.jar at all, it is only used to run the signed client which you shouldn’t be messing with anyway.[/quote]why not?

Read full topic

item.title: Initial Stack is null?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

It’s best not to mess with loader.jar at all, it is only used to run the signed client which you shouldn’t be messing with anyway. Write your own custom loader to run the runescape.jar and make it think it is running in the browser as an unsigned client. Or use Cherokee, which already has the dirty work done for you.

Read full topic

item.title: Initial Stack is null?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:4, topic:252364”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=333295.msg2597757#msg2597757 date=1230070220]

This renders decompiling impossible.

lolwut?
[/quote]Mmm, you get the idea.

I know what you are thinking though, but I’m too lazy to explain it.[/quote]

What are you talking about…? Decompiling is still perfectly possible, just recompilation afterward is highly unlikely. In fact, the loader obfuscation isn’t that bad, except in loader.class itself (especially the run() method).

Read full topic

I’ll go and try that now then.

item.title: Initial Stack is null?
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

The loader is (i believe?) obfuscated, just like the client. This renders decompiling impossible.

You should edit the loader via bytecode.

Read full topic
